journal-title-group.journal-title: Quarterly Journal of Finance and Accounting

publisher.publisher-name: College of Business Administration of the University of Nebraska-Lincoln

title-group.article-title: The Importance of Being Known: Relationship Banking and Credit Limits

abstract.p: This paper measures the importance of bank-firm relationships in obtaining higher credit limits. We use data from a relatively unused section of the National Survey of Small Business Finance, 1993 on credit limits, credit sources, and contract terms for firms with lines of credit from multiple banks. By looking at the difference in credit limits that banks provide the same firm we eliminate the need to control for firm-specific information and regard them as fixed effects. This method disentangles relationship effects from firm-specific effects. For a median line of credit of $250,000, we find that a bank with a five-year information advantage provides a line of credit limit that is $20,000 higher. We also find that purchase of loan and non-loan services by firms from the contracting bank affects the credit limit differently. Non-loan services increase the credit limit, and loan services decrease the credit limit. Our findings confirm anecdotal claims from the small business community that relationships are vital to secure higher credit limits.

p.mixed-citation: Pindyck and Rubinfeld (1991), Econometric Models and Economic Forecasts, pages 121-123
